title: How to Make Flower Butter

steps.headline: Prepare the apples.
steps.description: Core the apples, then chop into chunks.

steps.headline: Wash the honeysuckle flowers gently to remove any impurities.
Pour the water into a saucepan.
steps.description: Add the apples and honeysuckle flowers. Simmer for half an hour, or until the apples soften.

steps.headline: Push the apples and flowers through a sieve.
steps.description: Collect the apple pulp in a bowl below.

steps.headline: Weigh the pulp.
steps.description: Add the sugar according to the weight suggested (see Ingredients above).

steps.headline: Heat the apple pulp and sugar slowly.
steps.description: Stir constantly to help dissolve the sugar.

steps.headline: Cook over a low heat.
steps.description: Stir frequently. Cook until the apple flower butter thickens.

steps.headline: Spoon into clean, warmed jars.
steps.description: Seal and label.

steps.headline: Keep refrigerated.
steps.description: This will keep for up to 2 months.

steps.headline: Use.
steps.description: Simply spread onto bread, toast, bagels, etc. as a sweet butter substitute.

steps.headline: Purchase or pick a bunch of chives with the flowers still intact.
steps.description: The flowers should be in good condition. If picking your own, cut the stalks from the base of the plant.

steps.headline: Pull the flowers off the stalks.
steps.description: Pull apart the florets.

steps.headline: Add the chive florets to the room temperature butter, in a mixing bowl.
steps.description: Mix together.

steps.headline: Transfer the chive flower-filled butter to a small round or long dish to shape the butter.
steps.description: Alternatively, add to kitchen plastic wrap and roll into a sausage shape. Twist the ends of the wrap closed.

steps.headline: Place the chive flower butter into the refrigerator.
steps.description: Allow to set for a few hours. The flavor develops best over a few hours.

steps.headline: Remove for serving.
steps.description: If you've used the sausage wrap approach, cut the butter into small serving discs by slicing. They look especially lovely like this, as the butter is shot through with purple lines and petal shapes.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: The butter can be used on sandwiches or for crusty rolls in place of butter. Or, use it to make dishes taste better, such as grilled fish or meat, tucked into baked or hasselback potatoes, melted over steamed vegetables, added to sauces, etc.

steps.headline: Choose the edible flowers.
steps.description: If you're not sure what to choose, see How to choose edible flowers for some advice. Typical flowers for this butter would include rose petals, viola petals or nasturtium petals. Lavender buds can also be used. You can stick to one type of flower or mix types. Prepare the flowers by gently rinsing and patting dry to avoid bruising them.

steps.headline: Chop the flowers roughly.
Place the butter into a ceramic or glass mixing bowl.
steps.description: Add the edible flowers, along with the salt and pepper to taste. You can also add any fresh herbs you like, or other seasoning.

steps.headline: Place on a sheet of plastic kitchen wrap.
steps.description: Roll into a sausage shape. Twist the ends shut.

steps.headline: Place in the refrigerator to set.
steps.description: Serve after a few hours. Cut into slices or discs for serving.

text: Apple and honeysuckle butter Prepare the apples. Core the apples, then chop into chunks. Wash the honeysuckle flowers gently to remove any impurities.  Pour the water into a saucepan. Add the apples and honeysuckle flowers. Simmer for half an hour, or until the apples soften. Push the apples and flowers through a sieve. Collect the apple pulp in a bowl below. Weigh the pulp. Add the sugar according to the weight suggested (see Ingredients above). Heat the apple pulp and sugar slowly. Stir constantly to help dissolve the sugar. Cook over a low heat. Stir frequently. Cook until the apple flower butter thickens. Spoon into clean, warmed jars. Seal and label. Keep refrigerated. This will keep for up to 2 months. Use. Simply spread onto bread, toast, bagels, etc. as a sweet butter substitute. Chive flower butter Purchase or pick a bunch of chives with the flowers still intact. The flowers should be in good condition. If picking your own, cut the stalks from the base of the plant. Pull the flowers off the stalks. Pull apart the florets. Add the chive florets to the room temperature butter, in a mixing bowl. Mix together. Transfer the chive flower-filled butter to a small round or long dish to shape the butter. Alternatively, add to kitchen plastic wrap and roll into a sausage shape. Twist the ends of the wrap closed. Place the chive flower butter into the refrigerator. Allow to set for a few hours. The flavor develops best over a few hours. Remove for serving. If you've used the sausage wrap approach, cut the butter into small serving discs by slicing. They look especially lovely like this, as the butter is shot through with purple lines and petal shapes. Serve. The butter can be used on sandwiches or for crusty rolls in place of butter. Or, use it to make dishes taste better, such as grilled fish or meat, tucked into baked or hasselback potatoes, melted over steamed vegetables, added to sauces, etc. Edible flower compound butter Choose the edible flowers. If you're not sure what to choose, see How to choose edible flowers for some advice. Typical flowers for this butter would include rose petals, viola petals or nasturtium petals. Lavender buds can also be used. You can stick to one type of flower or mix types. Prepare the flowers by gently rinsing and patting dry to avoid bruising them. Chop the flowers roughly.  Place the butter into a ceramic or glass mixing bowl. Add the edible flowers, along with the salt and pepper to taste. You can also add any fresh herbs you like, or other seasoning. Place on a sheet of plastic kitchen wrap. Roll into a sausage shape. Twist the ends shut. Place in the refrigerator to set. Serve after a few hours. Cut into slices or discs for serving.
